generif.text: expression of the HMG box protein TOX is sufficient to induce changes in coreceptor gene expression associated with beta-selection, including CD8 gene demethylation

results suggest that TOX is required for IL-15-mediated natural killer (NK) cell differentiation and affected expression of T-bet that plays critical roles in NK differentiation and maturation

Compared with TOX4, expression of TOX1, TOX2 and TOX3 in normal lung was 25, 44, and 88%lower, respectively, supporting the premise that reduced promoter activity confers increased susceptibility to methylation during lung carcinogenesis.
SNP rs2726600 is located in a transcription-factor binding site in the 3' region of TOX.
TOX may be a specific marker for tumour cells in some types of cutaneous lymphoma.
High TOX transcript levels correlate with increased cutaneous T-cell lymphoma.
The SLC2A9 (rs7660895) and TOX (rs11777927) gene polymorphisms may be associated with formation of intracranial aneurysms, and rs7660895 may be associated with intracranial aneurysms rupture.
Significant associations between single nucleotide polymorphisms in TOX, CDKN2A/B and type 2 diabetes meillitus.
TOX expression is insufficient for diagnosis of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma
data suggest that GATA3 regulates TOX, revealing insight into TOX regulation
The expression of Sezary signature genes: FCRL3, Tox, and miR-214, was significantly higher in samples from Sezary syndrome patients with CD164 expressing CD4(+) T cells.
TOX gene SNP rs11777927 was associated with antipsychotic-induced weight gain.

TOX is an HMG box-containing protein that has important roles in T-ALL initiation and maintenance. TOX inhibits the recruitment of KU70/KU80 to DNA breaks, thereby inhibiting NHEJ repair. Thus, TOX is likely a dominant oncogenic driver in a large fraction of human T-ALL and enhances genomic instability
Suggest that F nucleatum may suppress antitumor immune responses by decreasing CD4(+) T-cell density and TOX expression in the progression of colorectal cancer.
hypothesis that TOX-induced exhaustion program serves to prevent the overstimulation of T cells and activation-induced cell death in settings of chronic antigen stimulation such as cancer

TOX is a critical factor for the normal progression of T cell dysfunction and the maintenance of exhausted T cells during chronic infection, and provide a link between the suppression of effector function intrinsic to CD8 T cells and protection against immunopathology
Molecular profiling of TOX-deficient neoplastic cells in cutaneous T cell lymphoma.
The VEGF-A induces the expression of transcription factor TOX in T cells to drive exhaustion-specific transcription program in T cells.
High TOX expression is associated with pathogenesis of atherosclerosis.
Single-cell transcriptome analysis reveals TOX as a promoting factor for T cell exhaustion and a predictor for anti-PD-1 responses in human cancer.
TOX is expressed by exhausted and polyfunctional human effector memory CD8(+) T cells.
Origin and fine-tuning of effector CD8 T cell subpopulations in chronic infection.
Increased TOX expression concurrent with PD-1, Tim-3, and CD244 in T cells from patients with non-Hodgkin lymphoma.
TOX Acts as a Tumor Suppressor by Inhibiting mTOR Signaling in Colorectal Cancer.
Normal and cancer fibroblasts differentially regulate TWIST1, TOX and cytokine gene expression in cutaneous T-cell lymphoma.
CD4+ T cells in classical Hodgkin lymphoma express exhaustion associated transcription factors TOX and TOX2: Characterizing CD4+ T cells in Hodgkin lymphoma.
The transcription factor TOX is involved in the regulation of T-cell exhaustion in neuroblastoma.
TOX promotes follicular helper T cell differentiation in patients with primary Sjogren's syndrome.
Transcriptional Pattern Analysis of Virus-Specific CD8+ T Cells in Hepatitis C Infection: Increased Expression of TOX and Eomesodermin During and After Persistent Antigen Recognition.
Immune checkpoint receptor VISTA on immune cells is associated with expression of T-cell exhaustion marker TOX and worse prognosis in renal cell carcinoma with venous tumor thrombus.
High TOX expression on CD8[+] T cells in pure red cell aplasia.
TOX regulates T lymphocytes differentiation and its function in tumor.
TOX, TWIST1, STAT4, and SATB1 protein expressions in early-stage mycosis fungoides.
Evaluation of mRNA Expressions of TOX and NR4As in CD8+ T cells in Acute Leukemia.
TOX as a new diagnostic marker for T cell large granular lymphocytic leukaemia.

interpro.desc: High mobility group box domain superfamily

name: thymocyte selection associated high mobility group box
other_names: thymocyte selection-associated high mobility group box protein TOX
thymus high mobility group box protein TOX

wikipathways.name: Development and heterogeneity of the ILC family

summary: The protein encoded by this gene contains a HMG box DNA binding domain. HMG boxes are found in many eukaryotic proteins involved in chromatin assembly, transcription and replication. This protein may function to regulate T-cell development.[provided by RefSeq, Apr 2009].
